abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Districts
            Development Project for Philippines were as follows:
            outcomes for public performance audit (PPA) was moderately
            satisfactory and for sewerage, sanitation and drainage
            development (SSD) was satisfactory; the risk to development
            outcome for PPA was significant and for SSD was moderate;
            the Bank performance for PPA was satisfactory and for SSD
            was moderately; and the Borrower performance for PPA was
            moderately satisfactory and for SSD was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: In the absence
            of an effective regulatory framework, the replication of
            public assessment of water services (PAWS) for utilities
            outside Metro Manila is unlikely to happen. Metropolitan
            Waterworks and Sewerage System (MWSS) has succeeded in
            securing sustainable financing for PAWS through the
            concessionaires- replicating the PAWS system outside Manila
            will depend on the extent to which the conditions for
            sustaining it can be created. Given the difficulties faced
            by National Water Regulatory Board (NWRB) in assuming a
            broader regulatory mandate as proposed under executive order
            (EO) 279, the expansion of PAWS outside Manila would require
            Government of the Philippines (GOP) action to revive the
            stalled reform process and make available adequate
            resources. The planned Local Government Support for Regional
            and Local Water Supply project will study the possibilities
            of expanding PAWS outside Metro Manila. When designing,
            implementing and managing complex sub-projects (such as
            private sector contracts for water supply or solid waste
            landfills), local government units (LGUs) often require
            specialized technical assistance and capacity building
            support from national government or the private sector. This
            support goes beyond routine capacity building in areas such
            as procurement, financial management and includes the
            participatory methodology, design of affordable tariffs, and
            establishment of regulatory frameworks. As most LGUs and
            Government Financial Institutions (GFIs) are unlikely to
            have this expertise in house, the borrower or implementing
            agency should ensure that the design of on-lending programs
            takes into account these technical assistance requirements.
            GFIs may also consider designing special financing
            instruments for special purpose subprojects.
